reviewText: John Wayne was in so many great films, but like any other actor he had his clunkers, too. The most infamous may be director Dick Powell'sTHE CONQUERER(1956), in which 6' 4" Duke portrays Genghis Khan, a Mongol warrior that was probably a full foot shorter vertically. Stupendous miscasting opposite Susan Hayward in Oriental eye makeup. This bomb is currently rated 3.3 (out of a possible 10) at IMDb.BIG JIM MCLAIN (1952) is another possible candidate for the Lingering Stink award. It was Wayne's first self-produced movie and it is winciningly bad at times. He's a HUAC invesigator looking for Commies in Hawaii. Duke does find some and also lands a wife, the now nearly-obscure Nancy Olson, who's best remembered as the script girl inSUNSET BLVD(1950) that catches William Holden's eye, thus making Gloria Swanson jealous.Duke Wayne was an unabashed flagwaver who gladly testified for the House Un-American Activities Committee on the Red Menace in Hollywood. Meanwhile Miss Olson was equally pro-Democrat, so the two were often arguing politics on the set. (BTW, she hated this film's script. Very prescient, in hindsight.)So when Wayne's not smashing evenly-tanned island Commies, he's wooing Nancy to the tune of "The Hawaiian Wedding Song," later made famous by Andy Williams. Incidental music is provided by William Lava, composer of Disney's "Zorro" theme, also the title song to TV'sF TROOP!Duke's red-bustin' cohort here is James Arness, a man who towers over him and is dimensionally larger in every way. Gordon Jones, then playing Mike the Cop on theAbbott & Costello Showhas a great comic restaurant confrontation with Wayne, a scene obviously "stolen," as other diners stop eating to watch the fun and laugh. These little moments, like Duke's amusing interactions with Veda Ann Borg, the brassy bleach-blonde big-mouthed GF of Jones, or a scene with Hans Conried as a coo-coo inventor, almost make "Big Jim McLain" a must-see, but too many times the story veers into lectures on the evils of Communism.So this is a product of its times, and since Wayne's new film company was footing the bill, it's heavily imbued with his politics.However, even with a 5.1 IMDb rating, Duke's fans still may want to see it.Available inTHE JOHN WAYNE FILM COLLECTION, a six-disc set of a half-dozen of his lesser-known pictures.It's a WARNER product, so transfer quality is fine. Each DVD includes a couple of short film extras.
Title: N/A

reviewText: First, my bona fides:  I'm a John Wayne fan; a staunch anti-Communist, who appreciates the work done by the House Committee on Un-American Activities and Senator Joe McCarthy; and I'm to the right of the Middle Ages.That being said, "Big Jim McLain" is unadulterated corn (what our Indian friends call "maize").  I don't have a whole lot of patience for unnecessary subtlety, but this film's treatment of Cold War threats has all the nuance of a sledgehammer.  "Ludicrous" is the word that comes immediately to mind on those rare occasions "Big Jim" enters the conversation.  Indeed, I always crack up when, at the end, the voice of Dan'l Webster inquires, "Neighbor, how stands the Union now?", and The Duke answers (indicating grinning and waving Marines), "There stands the Union, Mr. Webster.  There stands our Union, sir."  I of course realize that 59 years ago was a less cynical (and better) time than this.  Still, it's hard to believe that even 1952 eyes didn't roll at this exceptionally bombastic and self-satisfied claptrap.  (In fairness, though, no John Wayne film makes me laugh harder than "Chisum" -- its flatulent theme song has to be heard to be believed.)Despite it all, I like and recommend this movie; indeed, I've never seen another quite like it.

reviewText: This excellent movie about two detectives (6'4 (76) Wayne and 6'7 Arness) who search for Communism in the Honolulu area. The plot is realistic in the sense that the movie is about something that was happening in 1952. Many people don't like this, even though I don't know why. It has everything: comedy, action, scenery, adventure, remorse, etc. It is a switch for Wayne (who would make Hondo in '53 and The Searchers in '56.), but it shows how great an actor John Wayne is. This is a must-see movie for any fan of Wayne, big or small.

reviewText: Some have dubbed this a political thriller; others have denounced it as pure camp.  I prefer to think of it as another John Wayne movie: part history lesson, part propaganda, part travelogue, part romance, all fun.  Even the opening credits are a hoot, each blown away by the storm raging behind them.  A clear signal that this wasn't supposed to be taken so seriously, after all, the piece was riddled with humor (I especially liked the Dragnet type narration and approach).  To those who have gotten a bit prickly about the subject matter, think of this as a period piece that bespeaks of an age and an attitude prevalent during that time.  It's a bit late in the day to be offended by the Un-American Activities Committee (it was, after all, abolished in 1975).Watch the movie for what it is: a faux police procedural.  Does it work as such or not?  I found it mildly interesting, the characters colorful (Hans Conried as nutcase, Batman's butler the bad guy).  There were tips to collect, people to question (most with ulterior motives), Nancy Olson to woo, a jealous boyfriend to fend off, and a free-for-all fistfight.  The ending might be a bit unsatisfactory but that's the way it was.  I liked it and I'm keeping it to watch again.

reviewText: ---Unlike the majority of actors (politicians, etc.), John Wayne held strong convictions, and was unafraid to voice those convictions through his films, despite an inevitable backlash----"Big Jim McLain" is an example of his "conviction" films, and an interesting film on a subject very important to the majority of Americans in the late '40s- early '50's.....WWII had ended, and the iron and bamboo curtains had gone up around the world; nuclear warfare via the communist USSR was a very real and frightening possibility. Combined with the horrors witnessed by most US GIs during the war, communism was THE bogeyman--as well it might be, given the very high stakes involved.---Though certainly not a GOOD motion picture (shaky character development, use of "filler" storylines, and laughably over-the-top characterization), this film is important for its historical content and for an accurate depiction of the fears existing in the America of the early '50s. Enough action to not be a snoozer, and an all-around interesting film.

reviewText: Back when Hollywood was instituting the black-list, and the McCarthy's House Unamerican Activities Committee was violating civil rights, a few courageous souls stood up to them, pushed back, and defended the American way of life. But that's not what happened here.Without a trace of irony, John Wayne made a bad, bad movie starring as an investigator for the House Unamerican Activities Comittee gleefully violating civil rights, and breaking up a Communist Ring in Hawaii.Luckily, with 50 years between now and then, you can happily supply your own irony.The acting is bad, the pacing is terrible, and the entire thing hinges upon the unbalanced fears of McCarthyists. Although there is a romantic subplot, this is really a guy's movie.

reviewText: WW II was over and the Korean Conflict was winding down; but the Cold War between the United States and the Soviet Union was in full swing when this film was produced. If this John Wayne offering comes across as a war propaganda film to you, welcome to the club...that's the way I saw it too. Wayne teams up w/his off-camera friend, James Arness, who both play HUAC investigators searching for members of a Communist cell in Hawaii...tough work, but somebody has to do it, right? Before I get too glib, HUAC did do some legitimate work in uncovering Communist espionage cells in this country, including I suppose in what was then the territory of Hawaii. It was not all about the political grandstanding and red baiting of Joe McCarthy and others. Wayne turns in a good performance in this film, but nothing special; as does Arness...although he looks uncomfortable without western or military garb. Wayne, of course, finds romance - its Hawaii after all - and his romantic interest is Nancy Olson, a little used but capable actress. The bad guys are found and arrested - but not before Arness is killed by them - and Wayne and Olson ride off into the sunset...or something like that. Recommended.

reviewText: If you take this movie seriously and evaluate Wayne's actions as pro-American or un-American,  you may not like it, or even find it confusing.  In a like fashion, check out the Wayne movie "Green Berets".  Viet Nam Vets have been known to kick out their TV's when watching it because it made Viet Nam into a patriotic adventure.I sincerely respect people who challange the "reality" of some of Wayne's movies... especially when he interjects his politics.  I think the whole world knows by now that John Wayne made Reagan look like a pinko.Being an absolute Wayne fanatic, I simply view "Green Berets" as having to do with a fictional war in a far off place.  I don't hear "Viet Nam"....AND when I watch "McLain"..I view Big Jim as battling a bunch of "Bad Guys" and tune out the "Commie" business.  Doing this allows me to simply enjoy Wayne do his thing.  IF/When I want politics I watch the news channels.So cool it everybody and enjoy the biggest "movie star" in history (who turned himself into a pretty fair actor).
summary: "If You are a John Wayne Fan"

reviewText: It comes at the end, and it's not some cute scene with comedy undertones. What's remarkable about this film is it's stuffed with real Hawaii, and it's loaded with character, locations, beauty, and fauna. Rear projection is used about twice. The rest of the time...either outdoors, or interiors in homes or at hotels, it's all the real deal. And the hotels are gorgeous. Hans Conreid has a scene in this that throws the whole film sideways, but the message still sticks. It's not about commie sympathizers- it's really about saboteurs. This is an unusual script. Some of the people really have some moxie...the film is loaded with characters. Where's Claude Raines?And yes, that sock in the face. Somebody says something that you would never expect at all. And they get it.Note the DVD cover. He is never looking like this...it's always classic...suits.(Over hawaiian shirts)
summary: The Best Deserved Sock In The Face I've Ever Seen.

reviewText: Big Jim McLain is an interesting movie that is a result of the times it was made in, and that has to be considered when watching it.  John Wayne is Jim McLain, an agent for the Un-American Committee searching for communists living in the United States.  McLain, along with his partner Mal Baxter, are sent to Hawaii to find out who the Communist party leader there is as well as the ten secret party cells hiding out in the islands.  Also, McLain falls in love with a woman he meets during the course of his investigation.  This is a movie that is hard to explain; it needs to be seen to understand why.  It was made in 1952, which is evident throughout.  It might as well be a propaganda movie because of the stances taken, but don't get me wrong, that's why I'm recommending it.  Big Jim McLain is entertaining, campy fun that is sometimes unintentionally funny.  As well, the movie was filmed in Hawaii which looks gorgeous.  So for a very entertaining look at a different time in American culture, check out Big Jim McLain.In the title role, John Wayne plays government agent Jim McLain, a driven, dedicated man who stops at nothing in pursuit of his job.  But at the same time, he's frustrated that the people he's trying to get to are protected by the US government and Constitution.  Nancy Olson plays Nancy Vallon, a secretary who falls in love with McLain during his investigation and eventually get engaged.  Their relationship provide some of the movie's lighter moments and surprisingly works pretty well.  In one of his first bigger roles, James Arness plays Mal Baxter, McLain's partner who is as driven as Jim to stop communism because what happened to him fighting in Korea as a Marine.  Much of the rest of the cast is an ensemble who McLain and Baxter come across while searching for the Communist party members in Hawaii.  One that stands out is Veda Ann Borg as Madge, a woman who has involvement with the Communists and takes a liking to McLain.The recently released DVD, in conjunction with the Duke's 100th birthday, features a good-looking standard presentation in B & W, two Warner Bros. cartoons "So You Want to Enjoy Life" and "The Super Snooper", and a theatrical trailer.  So for an entertaining movie, if somewhat dated, but remember the time it was made, check out Big Jim McLain.  It's a different sort of movie for the Duke, but don't let that scare you.  And watch out for those Commies, they're cold blooded!
summary: An interesting Cold War era John Wayne movie

reviewText: Big Jim McLain was one of my father's favorite movies. He did like John Wayne, but I believe he liked it more because it was shot in the Oahu he remembered of the 1950s. He liked seeing the scenery in the movie and the scene with Honolulu Police Chief Dan Liu. I'm not sure if he followed the Duke's line of searching for hidden communists among Honolulu labor unions. I have seen this movie, too and I don't quite believe the suggestion that there was a communist sympathizer behind every labor leader but it was an interesting picture. It was also interesting to see the sunken Arizona before the memorial was built. The picture does end on a patriotic note, though as it focuses on soldiers headed for the Korean War.
summary: One of my farther's favorite movies
